entry.et: Middle English, from Old English, from Latin buxus, from Greek pyxos

def.dt: :an evergreen shrub or small tree (genus Buxus of the family Buxaceae, the box family) with opposite entire leaves and capsular fruits
:a widely cultivated shrub (B. sempervirens) used for hedges, borders, and topiary figures

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English, from Late Latin buxis, from Greek pyxis, from pyxos box tree

def.dt: :a rigid typically rectangular container with or without a cover a cigar box: as
:an open cargo container of a vehicle
:coffin
:the contents of a box especially as a measure of quantity
:a box or boxlike container and its contents: as
:a gift in a box
:an automobile transmission
:television
:a signaling apparatus alarm box
:a usually self-contained piece of electronic equipment
:boom box
:an often small space, compartment, or enclosure: as
:an enclosed group of seats for spectators (as in a theater or stadium)
:a driver's seat on a carriage or coach
:a cell for holding mail
:box stall
:penalty box
:a usually rectangular space that is frequently outlined or demarcated on a surface: as
:any of six spaces on a baseball diamond where the batter, coaches, pitcher, and catcher stand
:a space on a page for printed matter or in which to make a mark
:predicament fix
:a cubical building
:the limitations of conventionality trying to think outside the box
:to enclose in or as if in a box
:to hem in (as an opponent) usually used with in, out, or up boxed out the tackle
:a punch or slap especially on the ear
:to hit (as the ears) with the hand
:to engage in boxing with
:to fight with the fists :engage in boxing

entry.et: probably from Spanish bojar to circumnavigate, from Catalan vogir to turn, from Latin volvere to roll voluble

def.dt: :to name the 32 points of (the compass) in their order used figuratively in the phrase box the compass to describe making a complete reversal
:a box-shaped camera with a simple lens and rotary shutter
:a heavy overcoat formerly worn for driving
:a loose coat usually fitted at the shoulders
:a small cutting tool that is designed for opening cardboard boxes and typically consists of a retractable razor blade in a thin metal sheath
:a rapidly growing North American maple (Acer negundo) with compound leaves
